Name: Cyflufenamid
Description: Cyflufenamid is a member of the class of (trifluoromethyl)benzenes that is 2,3-difluoro-6-(trifluoromethyl)benzenecarboxamidine in which the hydrogen attached to the imino nitrogen is replaced by a cyclopropylmethoxy group while one of the hydrogens attached to the other nitrogen is replaced by a phenylacetyl group. It is used as a fungicide for the control of powdery mildew in cereal crops as well as in apple and pear orchards. It has a role as an antifungal agrochemical. It is a carboxamidine, an oxime O-ether, a member of (trifluoromethyl)benzenes, a difluorobenzene and an amide fungicide.

plant_translocations.content: The translaminar and translocative activities of cyflufenamid were evaluated. For translaminar activity, cyflufenamid exhibited excellent activity from adaxial to abaxial surfaces at 12.5 ppm against cucumber powdery mildew, while kresoxim-methyl did not show any translaminar activity even at 100 ppm. For translocative activity, cyflufenamid scarcely showed any activity against cucumber powdery mildew when evaluated using a root dipping method even at 50 ppm, whereas triadimefon showed excellent translocative activity at 3.1 ppm.
plant_translocations.reference: Haramoto, M., Yamanaka, H., Hosokawa, H., Sano, H., Sano, S., & Otani, H. (2006). Control efficacy of cyflufenamid in the field and its fungicidal properties. Journal of Pesticide Science, 31(2), 116-122.

method.Plant Grown Condition: Cucumber seedlings (Cucumis sativus cv. Hokushin) were bedded out in the greenhouse at Haibara Agricultural Research Center, Nisso, Shizuoka, Japan, on Sep. 2, 2000.
method.Chemical Preparation: Cyflufenamid was synthesized and formulated as a 10% WG.
method.Application Details for the Plant: Foliar spraying was performed on Sep. 26 (1 application) or Sep. 26 and Oct. 3 (2 applications) using a knapsack-type power sprayer with a water volume of 200 liters per 10 a. Disease severity in the field was evaluated on Oct. 3, 10, 17, and 25 using a disease rating scale from 0 (no apparent symptoms) to 4 (severe disease). The evaluation of fungicidal activity involved determining the area of visible lesions, expressed as the percentage of diseased leaf area ranging from 0-100%. The control value (CV) was calculated using the following equation: CV = (1 - T/C) x 100 Where T represents the percentage of diseased leaf area in treated seedlings and C represents the percentage in non-treated seedlings.
method.Other Information: The trial was laid out in randomized blocks with 3 replicates of 10 plants per plot.
